Merchant.title: Merchant
Merchant.description: Represents a car shop or merchant registered with the CarCheck-Flow system, primarily for LINE messaging integration and web management.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Merchant entity.

displayName.description: The public-facing name of the car shop or merchant.

lineAccessToken.description: Access token used to authenticate requests to the LINE Messaging API on behalf of this merchant. This token should be managed securely.

createdAt.description: Timestamp when the merchant record was created.

Vehicle.title: Vehicle
Vehicle.description: Stores information about a vehicle, including its inspection details and associated LINE user, managed by a specific merchant.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Vehicle entity.

merchantId.description: Reference to the Merchant who manages this vehicle. (Relationship: Merchant 1:N Vehicle)

lineUserId.description: The unique identifier for the LINE user associated with this vehicle. This user receives reminders.

inspectionDate.description: The date of the vehicle's next inspection.

status.description: The current status of the vehicle's inspection reminder process (e.g., 'pending', 'reminded', 'completed').

imageUrl.description: URL to the uploaded vehicle inspection certificate image in Firebase Storage.

definition.description: Top-level collection for car shops. Each merchant document must contain an `ownerId` field, representing the Firebase Auth UID of the user who manages this merchant, for authorization purposes.

params.name: merchantId

definition.description: Subcollection storing vehicle and inspection data, hierarchically nested under its managing merchant. Each vehicle document must contain a `merchantOwnerId` field, which is a denormalized copy of the parent merchant's `ownerId`, to enable authorization independence and secure `list` operations without requiring parent document reads (`get()`).

params.name: merchantId
params.description: The unique identifier of the parent merchant.

params.description: The unique identifier for a specific vehicle.

firestore.reasoning:
The recommended Firestore structure prioritizes Authorization Independence and Query-Aware Security Rules (QAPs) by using a hierarchical path for vehicles and denormalizing authorization context. 

1.  **Merchants Collection (`/merchants/{merchantId}`):**
    *   Each `Merchant` document will reside in this top-level collection. To enable authorization independence, each `Merchant` document **MUST** include an `ownerId` field. This `ownerId` will store the Firebase Authentication User ID (`request.auth.uid`) of the user who manages this specific merchant. This allows for simple, robust rules like `allow read, write: if request.auth.uid == resource.data.ownerId`.
    *   **QAP Support:** For listing, a client would query `merchants.where('ownerId', '==', request.auth.uid)`. Rules can then simply verify `request.auth.uid == resource.data.ownerId`, ensuring only authorized merchants are returned.

2.  **Vehicles Subcollection (`/merchants/{merchantId}/vehicles/{vehicleId}`):**
    *   `Vehicle` documents are structured as a subcollection under their respective `Merchant`. This hierarchical approach inherently links a vehicle to its managing merchant, aligning with the "Continue Hierarchy for Nested Data" mandate.
    *   **Authorization Independence:** To prevent security rules from requiring a `get()` call to the parent `Merchant` document (which would break atomic operations and complicate debugging), each `Vehicle` document **MUST** denormalize the parent merchant's `ownerId` into its own `merchantOwnerId` field. This means the `merchantOwnerId` in a `Vehicle` document will hold the same Firebase Auth UID as the `ownerId` of its parent `Merchant` document. This allows authorization rules for vehicles to be evaluated solely based on data within the `Vehicle` document itself, e.g., `allow read, write: if request.auth.uid == resource.data.merchantOwnerId`.
    *   **QAP Support:** For listing vehicles, a client can either query `merchants/{merchantId}/vehicles.where('merchantOwnerId', '==', request.auth.uid)` for a specific merchant, or use a Collection Group Query across all vehicles a user owns: `firestore.collectionGroup('vehicles').where('merchantOwnerId', '==', request.auth.uid)`. In both cases, the `merchantOwnerId` field in the `Vehicle` document allows the rule to operate on the document's own data, ensuring only authorized vehicle data is returned without complex server-side filtering.
